chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: Skin your jEdit!
The LookAndFeel plugin lets you choose between different non standard look and feel implementations for jEdit. Currently, the following look and feel implementations are included:

Other look and feels may be provided by additional plugins, for example, the popular Substance Look and Feel is provided by the SubstanceLookAndFeel plugin. This plugin will load the Substance Look and Feel plugin and any other available look and feel plugins automatically.

chapter.title: Configuration
chapter.para: To configure the Look And Feel plugin, open up the Plugin Options Dialog and select the Look And Feel Option Pane:
Plugins> Plugin Options> Look And Feel

sect1.title: Using jEdit Fonts
sect1.para: Check the Use jEdit Font check box to use the font specified under jEdit> Appearance under Global Options. Note that this is a hint only, and might not work on some Look and Feel implementations.

sect1.title: Selecting a Look and Feel Implementation
sect1.para: You can select from available look and feel implementations from the combo box labeled 'Look and Feel'. Some look and feel implementations will have extra configuration options that you may or may not need to configure, check the chapters on the individual look and feel implementations for details.

sect1.title: Saving Your Configuration
sect1.para: Once you Apply or Save these changes, the look and feel will be installed. Depending on the look and feel implementation, you might need to restart jEdit for all look and feel changes to be in effect.

chapter.title: The Skin Look And Feel (v1.2.10)
chapter.para: The Skin Look And Feel allows you to customize jEdit's look and feel based on themes. A theme is (roughly) a set of images, colors and properties, that defines the look of the GUI components.
Themes can be downloaded here. At the time of this writing, there are 10 themes available:

To install, select the theme pack you want to use from the LookAndFeel option pane in jEdit's Global Options menu. The themepacks are ZIP files, but you do not need to extract them. Just put the ZIP files in a directory of your choice.
More information on the Skin look and feel can be found at http://www.l2fprod.com

sect1.title: Configuring The Skin Look and Feel
sect1.para: To configure the Skin look and feel, just specify the path to your theme under the LookAndFeel option pane. You'll also have the option to enable XTra Scrollbars. XTra Scrollbars enables the grouping of scroll bar buttons.

chapter.title: The Oyoaha Look And Feel (v3.0)
chapter.para: The Oyoaha Look And Feel, like the Skin Look And Feel (see ), allows you to customize jEdit's look and feel based on themes. There two kind of themes you can configure in Oyoaha, the oyoaha theme and the metal theme (optional). The Oyoaha theme is the main theme, while some Oyoaha themes will use metal themes to configure various options like colors.
Themes can be downloaded here.

To install, select the themes you want to use from the LookAndFeel option pane in jEdit's Global Options menu. The Oyoaha theme files have the *.otm extension, while the metal theme has a *.theme extension.
More information on the Oyoaha look and feel can be found at http://www.oyoaha.com

chapter.para: Tonic tries to provide a clean, balanced look and an improved feel. Tonic is available free of charge both for commercial and non-commercial applications. It lends a professional touch and a very tidy and clean interface to Swing based applications.
The website for Tonic is http://www.digitprop.com/p.php?page=toniclf.

chapter.title: The Napkin Look and Feel (1.0)
chapter.para: The Napkin Look and Feel is a pluggable Java look and feel that looks like it was scrawled on a napkin. You can use it to make provisional work actually look provisional, or just for fun.
More information on the Napkin look and feel can be found at http://napkinlaf.sourceforge.net/

chapter.title: The JGoodies Look And Feel Family (1.2.2)
chapter.para: The JGoodies Look And Feel family (aka Looks) has been optimized for readability, precise micro-design and usability. And it simplifies the multi-platform support by using similar widget dimensions. Anyway, many people have reviewed it as elegant.
The JGoodies Look And Feel family consists of 3 different look and feel implementations:
The website for the JGoodies Look And Feel family is https://looks.dev.java.net/.

chapter.title: The Lipstik Look And Feel, version 1.1 (17 Mar 2008)
chapter.para: Lipstik look and feel is intended to be a Java (tm) Swing counterpart of KDE theme engine called Lipstik. This look and feel was written by Michal Buczko. This look and feel creates small, but very usable, components, which is great on a laptop where you would like to use your screen space for editing code rather than window decoration. A high quality and well finished look and feel.
The website for Lipstik is https://sourceforge.net/projects/lipstiklf/.
